laws.summary: Arizona enforces non-compete agreements but with statutory restrictions. A.R.S. § 23-494 allows non-competes that are reasonable in time, geographic area, and scope. Courts will reform unreasonable provisions. Non-competes must protect legitimate business interests. Generally employer-friendly but not as permissive as some states.
requirements: Must be reasonable in duration (no specific statutory limit, but courts typically find 1-2 years reasonable)
Must be reasonable in geographic scope (limited to area where employer conducts business)
Must be reasonable in scope of restricted activities
Must protect legitimate business interest (trade secrets, confidential information, substantial customer relationships, specialized training)
Must be ancillary to lawful employment relationship
Courts will reform (blue-pencil) overly broad agreements to make them reasonable
Cannot be used to restrain ordinary competition
Must be supported by consideration (new employment or continued employment with new duties/benefits)
Broadcast industry: Special restrictions apply (A.R.S. § 23-494.01) - cannot exceed 1 year, limited geographic scope
Physicians: Can enforce non-competes in certain circumstances but with limitations
laws.notes: Arizona statute specifically authorizes courts to modify unreasonable provisions. Federal FTC ban blocked in 2024. Broadcast industry has special protections.

laws.summary: Arizona has NO statewide salary history ban. Employers may ask about and consider applicant salary history when setting compensation. No state-level restrictions on salary history inquiries.
requirements: STATEWIDE: No restriction on asking about salary history
Employers may ask applicants about prior compensation
Employers may use salary history in setting compensation
No state penalties for salary history inquiries
Federal equal pay laws still apply (Equal Pay Act, Title VII)
Some employers voluntarily avoid asking for equity reasons
laws.notes: Arizona has not enacted salary history ban legislation. Employers have broad discretion.

laws.summary: Arizona has NO statewide pay transparency law requiring salary ranges in job postings. No requirement to disclose compensation ranges to applicants or employees. No pay data reporting mandates.
requirements: STATEWIDE: No requirement to include salary ranges in job postings
STATEWIDE: No requirement to disclose pay ranges to applicants
STATEWIDE: No requirement to disclose pay ranges to current employees
STATEWIDE: No pay data reporting requirements
Federal equal pay laws still apply
Employers may voluntarily disclose pay ranges
laws.notes: Arizona has not enacted pay transparency legislation. No posting requirements.

laws.summary: Arizona has limited ban-the-box protections. Executive Order 2017-07 prohibits state agencies from asking about criminal history on initial applications. Private employers generally can ask about criminal history at any stage. Must comply with federal FCRA.
laws.statute_citation: Executive Order 2017-07 (state agencies); Federal FCRA (15 U.S.C. § 1681); A.R.S. § 13-904(E) (employment discrimination based on expunged records)
requirements: STATE AGENCIES: Cannot ask about criminal history on initial application (Executive Order 2017-07)
PRIVATE EMPLOYERS: Generally can ask about criminal history on applications
PRIVATE EMPLOYERS: Must comply with federal FCRA
Cannot discriminate based on expunged or set-aside conviction (A.R.S. § 13-904(E))
FCRA: Must get written consent before background check
FCRA: Must provide pre-adverse action notice with copy of report
FCRA: Must provide final adverse action notice with dispute rights
FCRA: Seven-year lookback for most non-conviction records
FCRA: Ten-year lookback for bankruptcies
FCRA: No time limit on convictions
FCRA: $75,000+ salary positions exempt from lookback limits
Must consider: nature of crime, time elapsed, job duties, rehabilitation
Cannot discriminate based solely on arrest without conviction
laws.notes: Arizona is employer-friendly with minimal state restrictions. Federal FCRA provides primary regulation. Expunged records cannot be used.

laws.summary: Arizona has NO statewide paid sick leave or paid leave mandate for private employers. No state law requires employers to provide paid or unpaid sick leave beyond federal FMLA. Some local jurisdictions may have requirements, but state law preempts most local ordinances.
laws.statute_citation: No Arizona statute; Federal FMLA (29 U.S.C. § 2601)
requirements: STATEWIDE: No requirement for paid sick leave
STATEWIDE: No requirement for unpaid sick leave beyond federal FMLA
Private employers not required to provide sick leave benefits
Federal FMLA applies to employers with 50+ employees: up to 12 weeks unpaid leave
FMLA requirements: employee worked 1,250 hours in past 12 months, employed 12+ months, employer has 50+ employees within 75 miles
Employers may establish own sick leave policies
State law generally preempts local paid leave ordinances
No state penalties for lack of paid leave
laws.notes: Arizona has no paid leave mandates. Very employer-friendly state on leave policies.

laws.summary: Arizona generally enforces arbitration agreements under federal and state law. Follows Federal Arbitration Act. Arizona has enacted Uniform Arbitration Act. Agreements must be clear, mutual, and not unconscionable. Courts favor arbitration.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. §§ 1-16); A.R.S. § 12-1501 et seq. (Uniform Arbitration Act)
requirements: Arbitration agreements generally enforceable under FAA and Arizona Uniform Arbitration Act
Must be in writing and signed by both parties
Must have mutual agreement to arbitrate
Must identify claims subject to arbitration
Cannot be unconscionable
Must provide for neutral arbitrator
Adequate consideration required
Arizona courts favor arbitration
Class action waivers generally enforceable
Pre-dispute arbitration agreements enforceable
Can be challenged on contract grounds (fraud, duress, unconscionability)
Federal policy favoring arbitration applies
laws.effective_date: Ongoing under federal and state law
laws.notes: Arizona is arbitration-friendly. Courts enforce valid arbitration agreements.

laws.summary: Arizona follows at-will employment doctrine. Either party can terminate employment at any time for any legal reason or no reason. Exceptions exist for discrimination, retaliation, public policy violations, and breach of contract. Arizona is generally employer-friendly.
laws.statute_citation: Common law doctrine; A.R.S. § 23-1501 (Civil Rights Act - anti-discrimination); A.R.S. § 23-1502 (employment at will)
requirements: Default: Employment terminable at will by either party (A.R.S. § 23-1501(2))
No notice required unless contract/policy requires it
Final wages must be paid within 7 working days or by next regular payday, whichever is sooner
EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Race, color, religion, sex, age, disability, national origin discrimination (Arizona Civil Rights Act)
Cannot terminate for: Retaliation (workers' comp claim, jury duty, voting, military service)
Cannot terminate for: Violation of public policy (refusing illegal acts, exercising statutory rights)
Cannot terminate for: Breach of employment contract (written or implied)
Employment handbooks may create implied contracts if not properly disclaimed
Written employment contracts override at-will status
Union/collective bargaining agreements override at-will status
Arizona courts narrowly construe at-will exceptions
laws.notes: Arizona is strongly at-will employment state with typical exceptions. Handbook disclaimers recommended.

laws.summary: Arizona has NO state statute restricting private employer drug testing. Employers may conduct pre-employment, random, reasonable suspicion, and post-accident testing. Medical marijuana users have limited protections under Arizona Medical Marijuana Act (AMMA). Drug-free workplace programs may receive workers' comp premium discounts.
laws.statute_citation: A.R.S. § 36-2813 (Arizona Medical Marijuana Act); A.R.S. § 23-493.04 (drug testing and workers' comp); No general restriction statute
requirements: STATEWIDE: No general restriction on private employer drug testing
Pre-employment testing: Permitted
Random testing: Permitted
Reasonable suspicion testing: Permitted
Post-accident testing: Permitted
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: AMMA prohibits discrimination against medical marijuana cardholders
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: Employers cannot discriminate solely based on positive test for marijuana or cardholder status
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: EXCEPTION: Can take action if employee is impaired at work or used/possessed marijuana at workplace
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: EXCEPTION: Can take action if it would cause employer to lose federal contract or federal licensing-related benefit
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: No requirement to accommodate on-site use
RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA: No workplace protections (approved by voters 2020, effective 2021)
Workers' comp: Drug-free workplace programs can reduce comp premiums up to 5%
Recommended: Written drug testing policy
Federal DOT requirements apply to transportation/safety-sensitive positions
laws.effective_date: AMMA: 2010; Recreational: 2021; Workers' comp provisions ongoing
laws.notes: Arizona medical marijuana law provides limited employee protections but allows employer action for impairment. Recreational users have no protections.
